column1: "question": "what does doctors to do reduce morning headaches?"
"change your medications and implement productive lifestyle habits"
"text": "change your medications and implement productive lifestyle habits"
"passage": "you should also contact a healthcare professional if your morning headaches are accompanied by any other symptoms
column2: such as loud snoring
column3: vomiting
column4: or feeling tired during the day. in preparation for your doctor's visit
column5: consider keeping a journal next to your bed to record the frequency and intensity of your morning headaches. your doctor can run tests to see if you might have a treatable sleep disorder or other medical condition. they can also work with you to change your medications and implement productive lifestyle habits to help reduce morning headaches."

column1: "question": "how can students achieve the sleep needed to help them perform their best?"
"adhering to sleep schedules with parental support"
"text": "adhering to sleep schedules with parental support"

"passage": "a centers for disease control ( cdc ) study found that most american children and teenagers don't sleep enough. nearly 6 in 10 middle schoolers and at least 7 in 10 high schoolers don't sleep enough on school nights. of the high school students surveyed
column2: almost two - thirds sleep less than eight hours nightly. adhering to sleep schedules with parental support can help students achieve the sleep needed to help them perform their best. students'sleep schedules understandably loosen up during a school break. kids use break time to rest and recharge
column3: and there are often exciting things going on! however
column4: during short holiday breaks
column5: it might be best for children to try and stick to their regular sleep schedules."

column1: "question": "what can bright light therapy in the evening do?"

column2: helping you adjust to an upcoming night shift"
helping you adjust to an upcoming night shift."
bright light boosts alertness and suppresses the release of the sleep hormone
column3: melatonin. exposure to bright light can keep you awake and delay when you start to feel sleepy. using a bright light box before work or turning up the lights during a night shift may help you feel more awake. during periods when you are switching from one type of shift to another
column4: applying bright light therapy in the morning may help you shift your circadian rhythm so you wake up and fall asleep earlier. applying bright light therapy in the evening can shift your circadian rhythm later
column5: helping you adjust to an upcoming night shift."

column1: "question": "what are most modern mattresses made of?"
"passage": "most modern mattresses are made using various layers of foam material. commonly used foams include polyfoam
column2: latex
column3: and memory foam. within each category of foam
column4: one may find dozens of variations in density and firmness. because foam density is such a significant factor in the performance and feel of each mattress
column5: it's a good idea for mattress shoppers to understand foam density measurements. this article will explain how foam density is measured
column6: and what these measurements actually mean. it will also help guide prospective mattress buyers to select a bed with the proper foam density for their own comfort preferences."

column1: "question": "why do many people develop aches and pains in their back?"
"because their shoulders and hips are not aligned with their spines while they sleep."
"text": "because their shoulders and hips are not aligned with their spines while they sleep"
"passage": "some pillows sold today are specifically designed for people with torn rotator cuffs
column2: osteoarthritis
column3: and other conditions that cause shoulder discomfort. many people develop aches and pains in their back because their shoulders and hips are not aligned with their spines while they sleep. a pillow for back pain should support these areas to ensure even alignment. side sleepers can also improve their alignment by lying with a second pillow between their legs. most people snore at least once in a while
column4: but for many this is a chronic condition. the issue is particularly common for back sleepers because this condition can restrict airflow through the breathing passages if the head is not elevated."

column1: "in pill form approximately two hours before bedtime or administered continuously through a patch"

"passage": "dopamine agonists can be taken in pill form approximately two hours before bedtime or administered continuously through a patch. the fda has currently approved three dopamine agonists for rls : pramipexole
column2: ropinirole
column3: and rotigotine. a major side effect of dopaminergic drugs is augmentation ( progressive worsening ) of rls symptoms
column4: which can come in many forms. symptoms may appear earlier in the day
column5: they may become more intense
column6: they may spread to other parts of the body
column7: or higher doses of the drug may be needed for it to remain effective. these side effects could be mistaken for a natural progression of rls
column8: but they are typically reversed once the patient stops using the drug."

column1: "question": "what happens when atonia persists after a person wakes up?"
"passage": "people with narcolepsy enter rem sleep frequently
column2: often within 15 minutes of falling asleep
column3: and experiences normally found in rem sleep may bleed into wakefulness. when atonia persists after a person wakes up
column4: they experience sleep paralysis. if dreaming normally seen during rem sleep also continues during wakefulness
column5: it's experienced by some patients as hallucinations. hallucinations can be a frightening experience for people with narcolepsy. these hallucinations most often occur when someone is falling asleep
column6: but can also happen while a person is waking up. hallucinations are usually visual
column7: like seeing something or someone in the bedroom
column8: but may also be multimodal
column9: meaning they involve multiple senses
column10: like taste
column11: touch

column1: "question": "what kind of models of mattresses commonly have more substantial comfort systems and a softer feel?"
"passage": "the thickness of the mattress tends to correlate loosely with the firmness. thicker models commonly have more substantial comfort systems and a softer feel. on the other hand
column2: lower - profile models usually have thinner comfort systems and a firmer feel. this is a general trend
column3: but it is not a consistent rule. you can also find firm high - profile mattresses and soft low - profile models. we describe firmness on a scale of 1 to 10
column4: where 1 is the softest and 10 is the firmest. it's rare to find mattresses below 3 or over 8 on the firmness scale."

column1: "question": "why should those who value edge support should avoid mattresses that are extremely plush?"
"these will sink more around the edges when pressure is applied"
"text": "these will sink more around the edges when pressure is applied"

"passage": "latex or hybrid mattresses provide pushback that makes it easier to move around on top of the mattress. active sleepers with a penchant for all - foam mattresses should favor firmer models

column5: as these will sink more around the edges when pressure is applied."

column1: "question": "what should you do if you have frequently recurring nosebleeds
column2: or if your nosebleeds are concerning for any reason?"

column1: "passage": "do not change your medication without talking to your doctor first. nicotine use is associated with nosebleeds. this could be because smoking cigarettes causes inflammation in the nasal passages. quitting smoking can reverse this inflammation with time. for a nosebleed that you are unable to stop after 30 minutes
column2: you may need to visit the emergency room. if you have frequently recurring nosebleeds
column3: or if your nosebleeds are concerning for any reason
column4: talk to your doctor. they can help you identify the source of bleeding and cauterize it
column5: which can reduce your likelihood of having future nosebleeds. be sure to disclose any medications and supplements you take
column6: as well as any other symptoms or diagnoses you have
column7: so your doctor can better understand what might be causing your nosebleeds."

column1: "question": "why is meeting with a doctor important?"
"it can help determine whether any other sleeping problems or health issues may be causing symptoms like long sleep periods at night or excessive sleepiness during the day"

"passage": "many long sleepers only feel refreshed and alert during the day if they are able to sleep for an extended block of time at night. this may require establishing a consistent daily schedule that includes extra time for sleep. the american academy of sleep medicine recommends that people who are long sleepers consult their doctor if they feel concerned about sleeping too much. in addition

column1: "question": "who are the high profile box springs helpful for?"

"passage": "standard or high profile : the standard height for a box spring is 9 inches ( 22. 9 centimeters ). these high - profile box springs are often helpful for sleepers with mobility issues because a higher sleep surface may make it easier to get in and out of bed. low profile : low - profile box springs are typically between 5 and 6 inches ( 12. 7 to 15. 2 centimeters ). a low - profile box spring can give a more minimalist look to your bedroom. it's also important to consider how your box spring fits with the rest of your bedroom decor. you may need a lower or higher profile for your box spring to match the height of a bedside table or headboard."

column1: "text": "when the blood's co2 level rises above normal due to respiratory problems
column2: excessive metabolism"

column1: "passage": "hypercapnia occurs when the blood's co2 level rises above normal due to respiratory problems
column2: excessive metabolism
column3: or more rarely
column4: from breathing in too much co2. the body produces co2 as a byproduct of metabolism. some examples of events that can trigger higher - than - usual co2 production are fever
column5: steroid use
column6: eating too much
column7: and exercise. usually
column8: we regulate co2 levels by breathing in and out. however
column9: excessive production of co2 coupled with a compromised respiratory system may lead to higher levels of co2 in the body. severe breathing problems that interfere with a person's ability to regulate levels of oxygen and co2 are known as ventilatory failure."

column1: "passage": "later definitions have broadened the definition of trauma
column2: acknowledging the many sources of traumatic experiences and the effect of cumulative traumas. currently
column3: the diagnostic and statistical manual of mental disorders ( dsm - 5 ) indicates that trauma can be experienced either directly or indirectly. this means that we don't have to experience something first hand to develop trauma. for example
column4: teachers
column5: counselors
column6: and psychologists may develop secondary or vicarious trauma through repeatedly hearing about the traumas experienced by those they serve. whether indirect trauma can come from dreams may still be an open question. whether nightmares can cause trauma may also depend on a person's culture."

column1: "hallucinations that occur in the morning as you're waking up"
"text": "hallucinations that occur in the morning as you're waking up."
"passage": "hypnopompic hallucinations are hallucinations that occur in the morning as you're waking up. they are very similar to hypnagogic hallucinations
column2: or hallucinations that occur at night as you're falling asleep. when you experience these hallucinations
column3: you see
column4: hear
column5: or feel things that aren't actually there. sometimes these hallucinations occur alone
column6: and other times they occur in conjunction with sleep paralysis. for most people
column7: hypnopompic hallucinations are considered normal and are not cause for concern. they generally don't indicate an underlying mental or physical illness
column8: though they may be more common in people with certain sleep disorders."

column1: "question": "how long are you permitted to sleep in a mslt test?"
"passage": "mslt results provide information on sleep latency
column2: or the time it takes you to fall asleep after the technician turns the lights off. results also contain measurements of your brain waves and eye movements
column3: allowing technicians to interpret which sleep stages you experienced during your naps. if you fall asleep
column4: you are permitted to sleep for 15 minutes to see if you enter rapid eye movement ( rem ) sleep. by contrast
column5: if you are still awake after 20 minutes
column6: the nap opportunity is stopped and technicians record 20 minutes as the time it took you to fall asleep."

column1: "question": "where are sleep-related brain waves recorded in most animals?"
"in a part of the brain called the neocortex"
"text": "in a part of the brain called the neocortex"

column2: sleep includes stages of slow wave sleep and rapid eye movement ( rem ) sleep
column3: with distinct physical correlates such as a slowing heart rate or reduced muscle tone. in most animals
column4: these sleep - related brain waves are typically recorded in a part of the brain called the neocortex. fish do not have a neocortex
column5: but researchers have identified sleep - like brain waves in another part of the brain called the dorsal pallium. these brain waves are similar to slow wave sleep and rem sleep in other species
column6: and they occur along with characteristic changes in eye movement
column7: heart rate
column8: and muscle tone."

column1: "question": "how does oral appliance therapy treat sleep apnea?"
"by helping remove physical blockages from the upper airway."
"text": "by helping remove physical blockages from the upper airway"

"passage": "oral appliance therapy treats sleep apnea by helping remove physical blockages from the upper airway. mandibular advancement devices ( mads ) help clear the airway by moving the jaw forward
column2: while tongue - stabilizing devices ( tsds ) help clear the airway by moving the tongue forward. in children
column3: rapid maxillary expansion ( rme ) devices help clear the airway by permanently expanding the width of the roof of the mouth. research shows oral appliance therapies generally do not treat obstructive sleep apnea ( osa ) as well as continuous positive airway pressure ( cpap ) therapy. cpap therapy performs better than both mandibular advancement devices and tongue - retaining devices when it comes to treating osa."

column1: "passage": "because they help reduce physical blockages of the airway
column2: oral appliances aren't used to treat central sleep apnea ( csa ). people with csa experience lapses in breathing as they sleep due to issues with brain stem signaling
column3: not physical airway blockages. a mandibular advancement device ( mad ) connects to both the upper and lower teeth in order to advance or move the jaw forward. sometimes called mandibular advancement splints ( mas )
column4: or a mandibular protrusion device
column5: this type of device helps open the upper airway by moving the base of the tongue forward. this oral appliance is designed to be inserted before sleep
column6: then removed in the morning."

column1: "question": "what is narcolepsy type 1 disorder marked by?"
"the loss of neurons in the brain that are responsible for making hypocretin"
"text": "the loss of neurons in the brain that are responsible for making hypocretin"

column2: the exact causes and risk factors for each condition are not fully understood. narcolepsy type 1 is a disorder marked by the loss of neurons in the brain that are responsible for making hypocretin
column3: also known as orexin
column4: a chemical that helps regulate wakefulness and sleep. people with nt1 have a loss of 90 % or more of the normal number of hypocretin - making neurons. a genetically susceptible individual may experience damage to these neurons in an autoimmune fashion after an environmental trigger. some evidence suggests that nt1 fluctuates seasonally with a potential link to influenza ( flu ) virus."

column1: "question": "what is the average lifespan of most mattresses?"
"passage": "most mattresses have an average lifespan of 6 to 8 years. however
column2: your bed may last longer or require a replacement sooner than this
column3: depending on the mattress type. factors that can influence mattress lifespan include how often you use your bed and the quality of the materials. for example
column4: a memory foam mattress made with higher - density foam will usually last longer than a bed made with lower - density foam. the age of your mattress often indicates whether or not it's time for a new mattress. there are also some other signs to watch out for."

column1: "passage": "like how going to the gym regularly can tone up your arms

column4: sides of the throat
column5: tonsils

column1: "question": "how many americans support abolishing daylight saving time?"
"passage": "so we're used to it. but we can envision what life would be like without it. as of 2020
column2: 63 % of americans support abolishing daylight saving time
column3: according to an american academy of sleep medicine ( aasm ) survey. in fact
column4: 29 states have introduced bills to replace daylight saving time with one stable time
column5: with 18 passing legislation stating they'd change
column6: if they could. house subcommittee just discussed the matter on march 9
column7: as well
column8: with legislation passing the senate on march 15. what would happen first? we'd reduce schedule disruptions and having to remember which clocks auto - update."

column1: "question": "what is the threshold for indoor humidity?"

column2: so while warmer climates tend to feel more humid
column3: cooler air often has higher relative humidity. the best relative humidity for sleeping and other indoor activities has been debated. according to the environmental protection agency

column2: dementia is associated with changes in sleep structure. when we sleep
column3: our bodies cycle through a series of sleep stages
column4: from light sleep ( stages 1 and 2 )
column5: to deep sleep ( stage 3 or slow - wave sleep )
column6: and then dream sleep ( also called rapid eye movement or rem sleep )."

column2: but some high - profile models feature three or more. the thickness of comfort layers is often tied to mattress firmness."

column1: "question": "what determines how much pressure you place on a mattress?"
"passage": "a big part of our mission at sleepfoundation. org is to help you find the best mattress to improve your sleep quality. while mattress comfort often comes down to personal preferences
column2: body weight can have a major impact on how a bed feels. your body weight determines how much pressure you place on a mattress. in turn
column3: this impacts the bed's comfort. for example
column4: while a firm mattress may lack cushioning for a lighter sleeper
column5: that bed may strike the perfect balance between pressure relief and support for a heavier individual. to account for the influence of body weight
column6: we employ sleep testers of different weights
column7: ranging from less than 130 pounds to over 230 pounds."

column2: these two symptoms are known as vasomotor menopausal symptoms and can cause discomfort and a lower quality of life for women who experience them. vasomotor menopausal symptoms can begin in perimenopause

column4: vasomotor menopausal symptoms can also reoccur for post - menopausal women. the severity of vasomotor menopausal symptoms can vary dramatically from person to person and within the same person over time."

column1: "question": "what should you do if you want an extra boost with your nap?"

column1: "question": "how much longer do women sleep than men?"

column1: "memory consolidation - the process of preserving key memories and discarding excessive information - takes place during both the non-rapid eye movement (nrem) and rapid eye movement (rem) stages of your sleep cycle"
"text": "during both the non - rapid eye movement ( nrem ) and rapid eye movement ( rem )"

"passage": "scientists and researchers have studied the relationship between memory and sleep for more than 100 years. the general consensus today is that memory consolidation - the process of preserving key memories and discarding excessive information - takes place during both the non - rapid eye movement ( nrem ) and rapid eye movement ( rem ) stages of your sleep cycle. recent studies also suggest that insufficient and excessive sleep can affect memory processing and other cognitive processes. a good night's rest not only promotes good physical health but also enables our brains to function properly
column2: so getting the recommended amount of sleep each night is key to consolidating memories."

column1: "question": "what may falling asleep too quickly indicate?"

column2: such as insomnia
column3: narcolepsy
column4: or idiopathic hypersomnia
column5: a disorder in which a person sleeps too much each day. many experts consider it abnormal when a person falls asleep in less than 10 minutes. sometimes people fall asleep faster than usual because they are dealing with sleep deprivation or sleep debt
column6: the accumulation of sleep deprivation over time. taking sedatives
column7: including alcohol
column8: can also cause a person to fall asleep faster than usual. when a person is attaining adequate sleep each night and not taking sedatives
column9: falling asleep too quickly may indicate an underlying sleep disorder."

column3: we'll outline the basic characteristics of each firmness level. then

column1: "question": "what are the most important stages of sleep for physical and mental restoration?"
"passage": "each sleep stage plays an essential function
column2: but deep sleep and rem sleep are considered the most important stages for physical and mental restoration. alcohol initially acts as a sedative
column3: increasing the proportion of deep sleep at the beginning of the night. however
column4: as the alcohol's effects start to wear off
column5: the body spends more time in light sleep
column6: which is not as sound and may lead to more nighttime awakenings. as a result of these frequent awakenings
column7: people tend to clock fewer hours sleeping after drinking alcohol. studies have found conflicting information about how alcohol affects rem sleep."

column1: "question": "what type of lighting can make it easier to feel drowsy and doze off?"

"text": "lighting with a low color temperature and illuminance"
"passage": "light is the most powerful cue for your circadian rhythm
column2: part of your biological clock that helps regulate sleep. when it's time for bed
column3: you want to try to make your bedroom as dark as possible to reinforce a healthy circadian rhythm. blackout curtains can help if your room receives lots of exterior light. lighting
column4: including a bedside lamp if you use one
column5: shouldn't be too bright. lighting with a low color temperature and illuminance can make it easier to feel drowsy and doze off. another important part of controlling your light exposure is to minimize or eliminate the use of electronic devices
column6: including tablets and cell phones
column7: in your bedroom."

column1: "question": "what is the primary symptom in people living with alzheimer's?"
"passage": "changes in sleep quality and duration in older age are common. however
column2: the sleep concerns seen in people with alzheimer's are often more severe and complex. there may be a reciprocal relationship between sleep issues and the other symptoms of alzheimer's. this means that sleep loss can worsen other symptoms
column3: such as delusions
column4: restlessness
column5: and wandering
column6: which can
column7: in turn
column8: make sleeping more difficult. getting enough sleep and spending sufficient time in deep sleep and rapid eye movement ( rem ) sleep are necessary in order for preservation of memories to occur. memory loss is the primary symptom in people living with alzheimer's
column9: and compared to older adults without the disease
column10: alzheimer's patients spend progressively less time in deep sleep and rem sleep."

column1: "sleeping over more than two sleeping periods each day."
"text": "sleeping over more than two sleeping periods each day"

column2: the expectation is that they will sleep through the night in one block of time. that singular phase of sleep is called a monophasic sleep schedule. some cultures engage more frequently in biphasic sleep patterns
column3: sleeping at night and during a daily afternoon nap. polyphasic sleep schedules involve sleeping over more than two sleeping periods each day. these periods could be quick nap breaks throughout the day balanced with a reduced time asleep during the night. babies naturally follow a polyphasic sleep pattern until they are about three months old."

column1: "question": "how can parents reduce the number of middle ear infections?"

column2: parents can reduce the number of middle ear infections. pacifier use can also lead to a crossbite
column3: where the upper and lower teeth do not align correctly. however
column4: this problem often goes away once the baby stops using a pacifier

column1: "sensorimotor disorder characterized by a strong urge to move or adjust the legs that is typically accompanied by uncomfortable sensations"
"text": "a sensorimotor disorder characterized by a strong urge to move or adjust the legs"

"passage": "restless legs syndrome ( rls ) - also known as willis - ekbom disease - is a sensorimotor disorder characterized by a strong urge to move or adjust the legs that is typically accompanied by uncomfortable sensations. people with rls usually experience the most unpleasant sensations when they are lying down or sitting during the evening or nighttime hours. walking or stretching can temporarily alleviate the discomfort
column2: but symptoms often recur as soon as the person's body comes to rest again. studies show a consistent overlap between fibromyalgia and rls. since both conditions are associated with sensory abnormalities
column3: some patients may be misdiagnosed with fibromyalgia after demonstrating rls symptoms or vice versa. for some people with rls
column4: treating secondary causes of the disorder can reduce symptoms. people with fibromyalgia tend to experience sleep problems whether or not they've been diagnosed with a sleep disorder."

column1: "passage": "narcolepsy is a prominent example as it is a neurological condition in which the brain cannot properly regulate the sleep - wake cycle. narcolepsy affects around one in every 2
column2: 000 people and makes them prone to falling asleep rapidly
column3: including at inopportune times. neurodegenerative diseases including dementia and parkinson's disease are tied with sleeping difficulties and daytime drowsiness. traumatic brain injury ( tbi ) and concussions commonly cause sleeping problems
column4: and brain tumors or lesions may provoke excessive sleepiness. infections
column5: including meningitis and those that cause encephalitis ( swelling of the brain )
column6: can also lead to eds. neurodevelopmental disorders like attention - deficit / hyperactivity disorder ( adhd )
column7: which affects millions of children and adults
column8: cause a range of sleeping problems including daytime sleepiness."
